name: Sous Vide 101: Duck Breast
description: As a meat that is best served medium rare, duck breast makes an ideal candidate to cook sous-vide. By cooking it at 135°F for two hours, much of the fat under the skin begins to soften and render out while the proteins in it begin to set, making it much easier to crisp without shrinking on the stovetop just before serving.
totalTime: 1 hour or up to 4 hours and 15 minutes
recipeIngredient: 4 boneless duck breasts (about 5 to 6 ounces each; 150-175g)
Kosher salt and freshly cracked black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Season duck generously with salt and pepper. For best results, place on a plate and refrigerate uncovered overnight before proceeding.
Seal duck in vacuum bags. Place in 130°F (54°C) water bath for at least 45 minutes and up to 4 hours. Remove from bags and dry thoroughly with paper towels.

Place breasts skin side-down in heavy-bottomed 12-inch non-stick or cast iron skillet and set over high heat until sizzling, about 2 minutes. Reduce heat to medium and cook, moving and pressing breasts to ensure good contact between skin and pan until golden brown and crisp, about 5 minutes. Flip and cook second side until barely colored, about 30 seconds. Transfer to paper towel-lined plate and allow to rest for 5 minutes.
Slice breasts crosswise into 1/2-inch strips and serve.
